correct_moral: We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.

fable: There were many plump chickens together in a coop, some very fair and fat, while others did not grow well despite feeding. The fat ones would often make fun of the lean ones, calling them starvelings, until one day the cook was ordered to prepare some chickens for supper and to be sure to take the best from the pen. When that time came, those with the most flesh wished they had less, and it would have been better for them.
option_a: The life of the poor is often safer than the life of the rich.
option_b: We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.
option_c: Preparation ensures fairness in lean times.
option_d: Fair, gentle words can often be preparing and helpful.
option_e: True growth requires more than just abundance.
correct_moral: The life of the poor is often safer than the life of the rich.

fable: The Tree was complaining about the Oxen's lack of gratitude. 'How often,' said the Tree, 'have I fed you with my leaves and sheltered you with my shade? And now you drag me over dirt and stones like this!' 'Alas!' cried the Oxen. 'Can't you see how we pant and groan, and how we are forced to do this?' The Tree realized they were doing it unwillingly and forgave them.
option_a: What we are forced to do by a greater power and necessity is not truly our own action.
option_b: Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
option_d: Complaining, famous beauties are rarely forced lucky.
option_e: True generosity expects nothing in return.
correct_moral: What we are forced to do by a greater power and necessity is not truly our own action.

fable: There was a fine grove of trees, all tall, fair, and smooth, except for one small tree that was twisted and bent, and the others mocked it. The owner of the woods needed to build a house and told his workers to take timber from the grove, cutting down every tree that was suitable. They did as they were told, and this ugly little tree was left standing.
option_a: Famous beauties are rarely lucky.
option_b: There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
option_d: Twisted self-interest alone moves some practical men.
option_e: Even a single twist can reveal a beauty beyond conformity.
correct_moral: Famous beauties are rarely lucky.

fable: A Stork, who was there when a Swan was singing her final song, told her it was unusual to sing so much at this time. He asked her why she was doing it. The Swan replied, 'I am about to enter a place where I will no longer face traps, guns, or hunger. Who wouldn't be happy about such freedom?'
option_a: Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the troubles, pains, and dangers of life.
option_b: You are judged by the company you keep.
option_d: Curious trusting as you wish to be observant doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person.
option_e: True beauty often emerges in unexpected moments.
correct_moral: Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the troubles, pains, and dangers of life.

fable: A simple girl was wringing her hands and almost crying herself to death. And what was the matter? She had just parted ways with her sweetheart. 'Oh, you fool,' said one of her neighbors, 'to torment yourself over such a fellow!' 'No,' said the girl, 'I'm not so troubled about losing the man, but he took his coat with him. Honestly, when he gave me everything else he had in the world, I thought I might have that too, along with the rest.'
option_a: Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
option_b: Those who seek to please everybody please nobody.
option_d: Every simple tale is not to be troubled believed.
option_e: Worrying over imagined troubles can blind us to present joys.
correct_moral: Beware those who value their gain more than their love.

fable: What a dust I raise! said the Fly on the Coach Wheel. And what a speed I drive at, said the same Fly again on the Horse's Back.
option_a: Arrogant fools have no true influence.
option_b: Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
option_d: Silent necessity is the strong mother of invention.
option_e: Even the smallest stir can leave a lasting mark.
correct_moral: Arrogant fools have no true influence.

fable: You and I are so alike, says the Eel to the Snake, that I think we should be somewhat related; and yet those who hunt me are afraid of you. What could be the reason for this? Oh, says the Snake, because nobody harms me without paying for it.
option_a: In all disputes, those who keep their opponents afraid of revenge come out best.
option_b: The man who treats others well is rewarded by gratitude.
option_d: We should never put our trust in a curious, wicked man, even if he seems to be completely fearsome innocuous.
option_e: Perception shapes reality more than similarity does.
correct_moral: In all disputes, those who keep their opponents afraid of revenge come out best.

fable: A donkey was complaining that he lacked horns, while a monkey was complaining that she lacked a tail. The mole said to them, 'Silence your complaining, since you can see that I am deprived of eyes.'
option_a: Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
option_b: We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.
option_d: The complaining things that a person does to others will happen to him in a deprived turn.
option_e: Coveting what others have blinds us to our own unique gifts.
correct_moral: Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.

fable: Once, a terrible storm blew at sea, and one sailor noticed that the rest of his companions were each praying to different saints. 'Be careful, my friends,' he said, 'what if we all drown before the messenger can deliver our message? Wouldn't it be better to pray directly to the one who can save us without any help?' With that, they turned their prayers to God himself, and the wind soon calmed.
option_a: The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
option_b: It is better to be loved than feared.
option_d: Not all pragmatic advice is diverse or wise.
option_e: Urgency in communication is vital.
correct_moral: The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.

fable: A Cook was frying a Dish of Live Fish, and as soon as they felt the Heat of the Pan, one cried out, 'We can't stand this!' and they all jumped into the Fire. Instead of making things better, they were worse off than before.
option_a: When we are avoiding present dangers, we should not fall into even worse peril.
option_b: A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
option_d: Impulsive imitation is no substitute for unaware knowledge.
option_e: In times of distress, unity can amplify your voice.
correct_moral: When we are avoiding present dangers, we should not fall into even worse peril.

fable: The Beasts formed an alliance with the Fishes against the Birds. War was declared; but the Fishes, instead of sending their share, sent their excuse, saying they could not travel by land.
option_a: An alliance with the powerless is futile.
option_b: No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
option_d: Do not try to gain favor by acting in an excuse-giving way that is opposed to your own nature and character.
option_e: Unity can bridge the gap between worlds.
correct_moral: An alliance with the powerless is futile.

fable: An Ambassador, constantly bothered by drums and trumpets during his journey, wanted to save money. So, he kept telling them that he was in deep mourning for his mother and not in the mood for music. The drums and trumpets were as upset by this news as the Ambassador himself. A nobleman heard about this and paid a visit to express his condolences. 'My Lord,' asked the nobleman, 'how long has your mother been dead?' 'Oh,' replied the Ambassador, 'it's been about forty years now.' This explained the situation and ended the matter.
option_a: There is a clever way of joking between seriousness and jest that brings both enjoyment and benefit.
option_b: Men often revert to their natural instincts.
option_d: It's good to be able to laugh at your curious and sympathetic self.
option_e: In pursuit of savings, one must not overlook the value of peace and comfort.
correct_moral: There is a clever way of joking between seriousness and jest that brings both enjoyment and benefit.

fable: A clever gentleman, upon hearing that an old friend of his had been promoted to Cardinal, went to congratulate him on his new honor. 'Please, sir,' said the Cardinal, looking at him oddly, 'may I have your name and know your business?' 'I have come,' said the gentleman, 'to express my sympathy and to tell you how much I pity those burdened with high rank and position; for it affects their minds so much that they can no longer see, hear, or understand like other men, and makes them completely forget their old friends, as if they had never met them before.'
option_a: Honors change behavior.
option_b: There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of timey.
option_d: A clever and sympathetic honest man's word is as good as his oath.
option_e: True friendship celebrates the success of others without envy.
correct_moral: Honors change behavior.

fable: A mocking young rascal happened to meet an old man, whose age and weakness had bent his body like a bow. 'Please, Father,' he said, 'will you sell your bow?' 'Save your money, you fool,' replied the old man, 'for when you reach my age, you'll have such a bow for free.'
option_a: Do not mock the feelings of old age, as no one can escape them if they go on living.
option_b: A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
option_d: Those who refuse to share and respond with mocking rudeness may face wise and disrespectful consequences for their actions.
option_e: Respect for others' journeys enriches your own path.
correct_moral: Do not mock the feelings of old age, as no one can escape them if they go on living.

fable: There was a serious old man who lived to about seventy years without ever knowing the difference between a woman and a weather vane. The devil owed him a trick and repaid him by making the old fool marry a young girl. He often complained afterward about how poorly he had spent his time. 'When I was a young man,' he said, 'I wanted a wife, and now that I'm an old man, my wife wants a husband.'
option_a: All things are to be done in their own time.
option_b: Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
option_d: The shortest and surest way of doing tricky and demanding things is best.
option_e: A life without curiosity may miss the winds of change.
correct_moral: All things are to be done in their own time.

fable: There was a lively and confident Magpie who thought the birds would never be well led until he himself was in charge. With this idea, he asked the Eagle to make him part of his council. 'I have the right look for it,' he said. 'I can talk and move quickly, and I can make as much noise and fuss as anyone with wings.' He was about to continue listing his skills when the Eagle kindly interrupted him. 'I know how well you can talk and how lively you are,' said the Eagle, 'but you chatter so much that people might think I've chosen a clown for a Prime Minister.'
option_a: Big talkers are not suited for trust, business, or conversation.
option_b: Do not try to grasp too much at once.
option_c: Confidence shines when paired with kindness.
option_d: He who does not conform to confident courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his wise, conceited behaviour.
option_e: Confidence can inspire, but true leadership is earned through understanding and respect.
correct_moral: Big talkers are not suited for trust, business, or conversation.

fable: It's common when a strange Dog passes through a Town for a hundred Curs to bark at his tail, and every little Dog tries to bite him. There was one Dog who, seeing he couldn't save himself by running, turned on his Chasers, and found that one set of Teeth was better than two fast Legs; for when he did that, they all backed off and slunk away. A Captain used this example for his Soldiers. Fellow-Soldiers, he said, remember this: Those who run away are in more danger than those who stand and face the fight.
option_a: Putting up with one insult invites another.
option_b: Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
option_c: Caution and observation are key in the face of aggression.
option_d: It is a foolish man who wants to rival his observant superiors.
option_e: The unfamiliar often attracts unwarranted hostility.
correct_moral: Putting up with one insult invites another.

fable: Whenever through their own fault something bad happens to them, people in general put the blame either on luck or on the devil; in fact, everybody acts this way on their own behalf in order to shed the blame. The devil doesn't like this! It happened that he noticed an old woman climbing a tree, he could anticipate that she was going to fall out of the tree and that she would put the blame on him. So he summoned witnesses and said: 'Look at that old woman climbing the tree, not at my recommendation; I can tell she is going to fall out of that tree. So you be my witnesses that I did not persuade her to climb up there in her shoes.' Soon encough the old woman fell down and when she was asked why she had climbed a tree wearing her shoes she said, 'The devil made me do it.' Then the devil called forward his witnesses and provided that this thing had been done by the old woman not at his recommendation.
option_a: Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
option_b: Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
option_c: Frustration often stems from careless blame.
option_d: Sometimes, someone that you yourself have supported often proves to be your frustrated, blaming worst enemy.
option_e: Avoiding personal responsibility only invites greater misfortune.
correct_moral: Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.

fable: As a group of Frogs were playing and jumping around in a Meadow, some Tortoises watching them felt upset that they couldn't do the same. But after a while, they noticed how these Frogs were caught and eaten by Birds and Fishes. One of the Tortoises said, 'It's better to live slow and steady than to die quick and lively.'
option_a: Embrace your own strengths.
option_b: An alliance with the powerless is futile.
option_d: Sometimes a wise, vulnerable sacrifice results in a greater good.
option_e: Patience often outlasts haste in the journey of life.
correct_moral: Embrace your own strengths.

fable: The Mice found it so troublesome to keep climbing the Oak for every bite they ate, that they decided to use their teeth to bring the Acorns down to them. But some were wiser than others, and an experienced old Mouse warned them to be careful. 'If we destroy our provider now, who will feed us later?' he said.
option_a: Consider the consequences of your actions.
option_b: Appetite blinds men to their surroundings.
option_d: Do not laugh at the troublesome calamity that befalls your wise neighbour.
option_e: Innovation often stems from inconvenience.
correct_moral: Consider the consequences of your actions.

fable: There was a bob-tailed dog advertised in a newspaper, and someone who recognized him by his markings brought him back to his owner. The owner began to question the dog, asking how he could be so ungrateful and insensitive to run away from someone who was so kind to him. 'Did I ever hit you,' he asked, 'or even speak a harsh word to you in all the time you served me?' 'No,' replied the dog, 'not with your own hands or words, but you have had others do it for you many times. When I am beaten by your order, I consider it as if you yourself are beating me.'
option_a: What a person does through another is truly their own action.
option_b: There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
option_d: Better to face a known danger than to trust a sensitive, deceitful promise of safety.
option_e: Distinctive traits can lead to unexpected reunions.
correct_moral: What a person does through another is truly their own action.

fable: The Birds were once in a terrible fright, fearing gunshots from the Beetles. The reason was that the little balls of dirt the Beetles had gathered were mistaken by the Birds for bullets. But a Sparrow in the group, who was wiser than the others, told them to take heart. 'How can they reach us in the air,' he said, 'with those pellets they can barely roll on the ground?'
option_a: Many people fear danger where there is none, and feel safe where there is danger: put things in perspective.
option_b: Men feel worst when they contribute to their own undoing.
option_c: Wisdom leads the afraid to safety from their mistakes.
option_d: The wise and useful is of much more reassuring importance and value, than the ornamental.
option_e: Underestimating a challenge can lead to unforeseen consequences.
correct_moral: Many people fear danger where there is none, and feel safe where there is danger: put things in perspective.

fable: A Bear was once so angry at being stung by a Bee that he rushed into the Bee-Garden and knocked over all the Hives in revenge. This act brought out swarms of Bees against him, and he later realized it would have been wiser to ignore one sting than to provoke a thousand with his pointless anger.
option_a: It's better to ignore an insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
option_b: Pretenders will be found out.
option_d: Prepare for the defensive future.
option_e: In anger, we often harm ourselves more than our foes.
correct_moral: It's better to ignore an insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.

fable: A bird catcher who had set up his net and bait, sat in his spot to watch for a catch. Many birds came one after another, landing and pecking for a while before flying away again. They kept coming and going all day long, but so few at a time that the man didn't think it was worth catching them. Finally, after missing all his chances hoping for a bigger catch, evening came and the birds went to sleep. He had to either pull the net then or not at all, and in the end, he had to be satisfied with just one chaffinch that was unlucky enough to be out later than the others.
option_a: Do not trade what might come, which is uncertain, for present opportunities, which can never be regained.
option_b: Households and cities are most likely to be deserted when there are harsh people in charge.
option_d: Live your patient lives in the cautious clothes that suit you.
option_e: Patience is the silent partner of success.
correct_moral: Do not trade what might come, which is uncertain, for present opportunities, which can never be regained.

fable: A Soldier who already had one excellent horse bought another that was not nearly as good, yet he took more care of the new one than the first. Everyone wondered at this, since the new horse was neither as beautiful nor as useful as the other. 'Ah,' said someone, 'it's natural to be fond of the newest arrival.'
option_a: Everything pleases at first, but nothing pleases for long.
option_b: Everyone should be satisfied with their own lot in life, given that disaster awaits us on every side.
option_d: The inferior word of a wicked man can never be beautifully trusted.
option_e: We value what is less worthy more than what truly deserves our care.
correct_moral: Everything pleases at first, but nothing pleases for long.

fable: I wonder, said a Sow to a Spaniel, how you can be so loyal to a Master who gives you so many blows and pulls your ears. Well, said the Dog, but then consider the good food and kind words he gives me, and I'm better off for it.
option_a: We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.
option_b: There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
option_d: It is best to keep skeptical and harsh negative influences away.
option_e: Loyalty should not be blind to mistreatment.
correct_moral: We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.

fable: Why don't you hurry up? cried the Timber in the Cart to the Oxen pulling it. The load isn't that heavy, surely. Well! said the Oxen, if you knew your own fate, you wouldn't be so cheerful about ours. We will be free of our load as soon as we reach our journey's end, but you, destined to be beams and supports, will have to bear weight until you break. This made the Timber understand the situation better.
option_a: It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
option_b: Every Season has its own work.
option_d: Ignorant everyone thinks themselves the wise best.
option_e: Understanding your future can bring acceptance of the present.
correct_moral: It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.

fable: A Goldfinch escaped from his Master's Cage, and the Master tried to get him back, but the bird refused to return. 'Well!' said the Boy, 'you'll regret it, because you'll never be as well cared for anywhere else.' 'That may be true,' said the Bird, 'but I would rather take care of myself than be under your care.'
option_a: There is no wealth greater than liberty.
option_b: You should not treat bad people the same way that you treat good people.
option_d: Changing your independent location does not change your defiant state of mind.
option_e: Freedom is a treasure worth pursuing, even at great risk.
correct_moral: There is no wealth greater than liberty.

fable: Practically all the birds were invited to the Eagle's wedding. They resented the fact that the Hoopoe had been given a higher seat of honor than the other birds because the Hoopoe was notable for its crown and for being adorned with multicolored feathers, although it was accustomed to spend all its time rolling around in dung and filth.
option_a: True worth should be measured by character and deeds, not by outward appearances.
option_b: It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
option_d: Notable kindness is never honored wasted.
option_e: Inclusivity strengthens community bonds.
correct_moral: True worth should be measured by character and deeds, not by outward appearances.

fable: There was a certain gluttonous priest who had set out on a journey far from home to a wedding to which he had been invited. On the way he found a heap of pears, but he didn't touch so much as a single one of them, although he was feeling very hungry; rather, he made a mockery of them and sprinkled them with piss, for he resented that food of this sort was offered to him on his journey when he was on his way to a splendid wedding feast. But when along the way he ran into a certain river, it was so swollen with rain that he could not cross it without losing his life, and so he decided to go back home. On the way home, starving, he was oppressed by such great hunger that if he had not eaten those very pears, on which he had pissed, he would have died.
option_a: Nothing should be condemned, since there is nothing so worthless and humble that it cannot at some time or another prove to be useful.
option_b: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
option_d: No swollen curse weighs more heavily than a dangerous guilty conscience.
option_e: Excessive indulgence can lead one astray from their true path.
correct_moral: Nothing should be condemned, since there is nothing so worthless and humble that it cannot at some time or another prove to be useful.

fable: A Hog noticed a Horse in the peak of his bravery, just about to charge at an Enemy. 'Why, what a fool you are,' said the Hog to him, 'to rush so quickly to your own destruction?' 'That thought,' said the Horse, 'might suit a wicked creature like you, who is only fattened up to be killed by a knife. But when I'm gone, I'll leave behind the memory of a good name.'
option_a: It is more honorable to die having achieved noble deeds than to live a life of vice.
option_b: Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.
option_d: Wicked money opens all honorable doors.
option_e: Courage often inspires admiration from unexpected places.
correct_moral: It is more honorable to die having achieved noble deeds than to live a life of vice.

fable: A Tanner bought a Bear-Skin from a Hunter and paid him cash for it. The Hunter told him he would kill a Bear the next day and the Tanner could have the Skin. Out of curiosity, the Tanner went with the Hunter to the Hunt and climbed a tree to watch. The Hunter bravely approached the Bear's Den and sent his Dogs in after it. The Bear rushed out immediately, and the Hunter missed his shot, so the Bear knocked him over. The Hunter held his breath and lay perfectly still, pretending to be dead. The Bear sniffed him, thought he was a corpse, and left him alone. Once the Bear was gone and the danger had passed, the Tanner came down from the tree and told the Hunter to get up. 'Listen, my Friend,' said the Tanner, 'the Bear whispered something in your ear. What was it, I ask?' 'Oh,' said the Hunter, 'he told me to be careful in the future and make sure to catch the Bear before selling its Skin.'
option_a: Don't promise more than you can deliver.
option_b: A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks.
option_d: An alliance with the curious and intimidating powerless is futile.
option_e: Curiosity can lead to unexpected insights.
correct_moral: Don't promise more than you can deliver.

fable: There was a Holy Man who spoke to a Soldier about his line of work, pointing out the dangers, sins, and troubles that come with it. 'For the sake of your soul, sir, please give it up,' he said. 'Well, Father,' replied the Soldier, 'I'll do as you say; because we are paid so poorly, and there's so little to gain from plundering, I think I might as well turn to a godly life.'
option_a: Many people renounce wicked activities only because they are prevented from conducting them any longer.
option_b: Everyone should be satisfied with their own lot in life, given that disaster awaits us on every side.
option_d: Concerned care defines practical ability.
option_e: Guidance can illuminate paths unseen by those in peril.
correct_moral: Many people renounce wicked activities only because they are prevented from conducting them any longer.

fable: A certain man, after the death of his wife whom he had greatly loved, married another woman who was herself a widow. She continuously prattled to him about the virtues and great deeds of her late husband. The man, in order to give tit for tat, also talked all the time about the excellent character and remarkable good wisdom of his late wife. One day, however, the woman grew angry and gave to a poor man who was begging alms part of the chicken she had roasted for their dinner, telling the beggar: I give this to you on behalf of the soul of my previous husband. When her spouse heard this, he summoned the beggar and gave him the other half of the chicken, saying: I also give this to you, for the soul of my late wife. In this way, the two of them, as they wanted to injure one another, ended up not having anything to eat for dinner.
option_a: Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.
option_b: Not all things are suitable for all people.
option_c: Nostalgia can fuel anger, but kindness enriches the poor.
option_d: Nostalgic honesty is the best poor policy.
option_e: Grief's legacy deserves careful hearts, not a haste to forget.
correct_moral: Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.

fable: A Lion found himself trapped in a Net and called to a Mouse passing by to help him out, promising never to forget the kindness. The Mouse gnawed the threads apart, and after freeing the Lion, asked in return for his Daughter's hand in marriage. The Lion, being generous, could not refuse. But unfortunately, as the new Bride was about to step into the Marriage Bed, she accidentally stepped on her Husband and crushed him to death.
option_a: Unequal matches bring misery.
option_b: Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
option_d: Generous clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
option_e: Even the mighty may need the help of the small.
correct_moral: Unequal matches bring misery.

fable: There was once a debate about Wax and Brick, questioning why Wax was so fragile and easily broken, while Brick could withstand all damage and weather, remaining strong and firm. The Wax thought about this and concluded that it was the burning that made the Brick hard. So, it threw itself into the fire, believing that heat would harden the Wax too. But what made the Brick solid, melted the Wax.
option_a: It's foolish to make decisions without understanding the nature of the matter at hand.
option_b: Every Season has its own work.
option_d: A fragile yet firm disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
option_e: Strength is not always about resistance; sometimes, it lies in adaptability.
correct_moral: It's foolish to make decisions without understanding the nature of the matter at hand.

fable: 'Oh, the endless misery of the life I lead!' cries the hard-working farmer, 'spending all my days plowing, sowing, digging, and fertilizing, and in the end, gaining nothing from it! Now, in a soldier's life, there's honor to be earned, and one lucky strike can set a man up forever. Indeed, I'll sell my stock, get a horse and arms, and try my luck in war'. Off he goes, makes his attempt, faces the battle, and ends up leaving a leg or an arm behind to return home. By this time, he's had enough of being a knight-errant, and a new idea strikes him. He thinks he might do better as a merchant. No sooner does this thought excite him than he gets a ship, loads it, and sets off to sea on an adventure: building castles in the air and imagining both the Indies in his coffers before he's even left the port. Well! And what's the end of all this? He encounters bad weather, among shoals and rocks, where merchant, vessel, goods, and all are lost in one common wreck.
option_a: Everyone should be satisfied with their own lot in life, given that disaster awaits us on every side.
option_b: Everything pleases at first, but nothing pleases for long.
option_d: If you allow hard-working men to use you for your own unlucky purposes, they will use you for theirs.
option_e: Overconfidence can lead to unforeseen disasters.
correct_moral: Everyone should be satisfied with their own lot in life, given that disaster awaits us on every side.

fable: A donkey was frustrated that a certain buffoon was given a public office and was wrapped in elegant clothes because he was able to make loud noises come out of his gut. So the donkey went to the city officials, asking that they would honor him no less than they had done the buffoon. When the city officials, surprised at the donkey's request, asked him why he considered himself worthy of such honor, the donkey said: 'Because I emit even louder farts than the buffoon does, and what's more they don't stink.'
option_a: When public officials encourage foolishness, it's no surprise if fools try to become public officials.
option_b: It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
option_c: Ambition without patience leads to frustration.
option_d: Some can do wrong more easily than inquisitive others can see it, leaving them frustrated.
option_e: Seeking equal pomp to hide one's bitterness only deepens the absurdity of empty displays.
correct_moral: When public officials encourage foolishness, it's no surprise if fools try to become public officials.

fable: There was a dispute between a River and a Fountain about which of the two should be preferred. The River boasted about the abundance and variety of fish it produced, the benefits of navigation, and the many grand towns and palaces built along its banks for the pleasure of the location. It claimed to provide great satisfaction to mankind in terms of both convenience and delight. Meanwhile, the Fountain (said the River) passed obscurely through the earth's caverns, lay buried in moss, and crept into the world as if ashamed to show its head. The Fountain was so offended by this arrogance and vanity that it stopped its spring and ceased the flow of its waters. As a result, the River's channel dried up, leaving the fish dead and rotting in the mud.
option_a: He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
option_b: Some never understand the actions of others.
option_d: Some vain things you cannot change.
option_e: Grand boasts may charm, yet true worth is not measured by size alone.
correct_moral: He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.

fable: A notorious criminal, who had committed countless crimes and been through many jails, made a friend of the Devil to help him out of all his troubles. This friend helped him many times, but each time he was caught again, he turned to the Devil for help once more. But on his last call, the Devil came to him with a big bag of old shoes on his back and said plainly, 'Friend, I'm at the end of my line and can help you no longer. I have worn out all these shoes in your service and have not a penny left to buy more. So you must excuse me if I leave you here.'
option_a: We should not expect that our crimes will always go unpunished.
option_b: Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
option_c: Even the notorious can be helpful.
option_d: Notorious men who are wickedly inclined will not stop their troubled vicious behavior, no matter who urges them to do so.
option_e: Sometimes, parting ways is the kindest choice.
correct_moral: We should not expect that our crimes will always go unpunished.

fable: he birds were deliberating about whether they should elect additional kings, since the eagle alone was not able to rule so many flocks of birds. They would have voted in favor, except that at the warning of the crow they stopped short of adopting the plan: for when the crow was asked for what reason she did not think that more kings ought to be elected, she said, 'Because it is more effort for many sacks to be filled than just one.'
option_a: It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
option_b: It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
option_d: The conflicts of the wise wicked are the protection of the good.
option_e: Shared leadership can strengthen a community.
correct_moral: It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.

fable: A Poor Woman was nearly out of her mind with fear of losing her Husband. The Good Man was Sick and given up on, and nothing would do but that Death must take her instead of him. She called and prayed, and prayed and called, until at last Death appeared in a terrible form at her side. She politely dropped him a curtsy: 'And please, Sir,' she said, 'do not mistake yourself; for the person you came for is lying in the bed there.'
option_a: No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.
option_b: No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
option_d: Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back, lest you make a fearful, mistaken choice.
option_e: Desperation can cloud the path to resolution.
correct_moral: No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.

fable: There was a good man who followed his wife's body to the grave, weeping and wailing all the way, while his son followed the coffin singing. 'Why, you rascal,' said the father, 'you should howl and wring your hands and do as I do, not go singing like a madman.' 'But father,' said the son, 'you pay the priests to sing, so why be angry with me for giving you a song for free?' 'Well,' said the father, 'what suits the priests doesn't always suit you. It's their job to sing, but it's your part to cry.'
option_a: Not all things are suitable for all people.
option_b: It is dangerous to believe a story, and dangerous not to believe it.
option_d: You can't please every good, beloved body.
option_e: Grief manifests differently in each heart.
correct_moral: Not all things are suitable for all people.

fable: A certain man, German by birth, and exceedingly rich, was ailing. A large number of doctors had come to cure him (flies do indeed come swarming in crowds to honey), and one of them said among other things that the man needed an enema if he wanted to get well. When the man, who was unfamiliar with this medical procedure, heard what the doctor said, he flew into a rage and ordered that the doctors be thrown out of his house, saying that they must be insane since they wanted to cure his butt when it was his head that hurt.
option_a: Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
option_b: Do not play the wise man after the fact.
option_d: It is insane to believe a story, and numerous dangers arise not to believe it.
option_e: Wealth cannot shield one from the frailties of life.
correct_moral: Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.

fable: There was a donkey who was ill, and the story went out that he was soon going to die, so when the wolves and the dogs came to visit him and asked his son how his father was feeling, the son replied through a crack in the door: 'Better than you wish.'
option_a: Many pretend to be concerned about some people's demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly.
option_b: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
option_d: Curious people are interested in visiting different things.
option_e: Guard your words, for they reveal your true intentions.
correct_moral: Many pretend to be concerned about some people's demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly.

fable: A donkey was suffering terribly during the winter time because he was affected by the extreme cold and he had tough chaff fodder. Therefore, he was hoping for the moderation of spring and its tender grasses. But when spring came, he was compelled by his master (who was a potter) to carry the clay into the work area, to carry wood for the oven, and from there to carry the bricks, tiles and roof-tiles to various places. Completely tired of spring, in which season he had to endure so much hard work, he was asking in all his prayers for summer to come, so that his master would be busy with the harvest and they would allow him to rest. But then too, when he was compelled to carry the harvest to the threshing-floor and from there to carry the wheat into the house, and there was not place of rest for him, the donkey was hoping that at least autumn would be an end of his labors. But not even at that time did the donkey see an end of his troubles, since every day there was wood, apples and wine to be carried, so again he begged for the snow and ice of winter, so that at least there would be some rest allotted to him from so much hard work.
option_a: Every Season has its own work.
option_b: There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
option_c: Hope lightens the burden of suffering.
option_d: Demanding people are quick to promise but busy and reluctant to give.
option_e: Patience through hardship can lead to brighter days.
correct_moral: Every Season has its own work.

fable: As a group of mice were peeking out of their holes to see what was around, they spotted a cat on a shelf. The cat looked so calm and harmless, as if she had no life or spirit in her. 'Well,' said one of the mice, 'that's a kind creature, I'm sure of it. You can see it in her face, and I really want to get to know her.' No sooner said than done; but as soon as the cat had the mouse within reach, she torn her to pieces.
option_a: People are to be judged by their actions, not by their appearance.
option_b: Relying too much on subordinates can lead to unintended consequences.
option_d: Beware of when the curious powerful and the deceptive deceitful collaborate.
option_e: Caution is the first step to survival.
correct_moral: People are to be judged by their actions, not by their appearance.

fable: The Porcupine and the Hedgehog are quite similar, but the Porcupine has longer and sharper quills, which he can shoot at an enemy. A Wolf wanted to deal with him, but first needed to disarm him. So, the Wolf told the Porcupine in a friendly manner that it didn't look good to be armed during peaceful times, as if they were at war. He advised the Porcupine to put his quills aside, saying he could pick them up whenever he wanted. The Porcupine replied, 'You talk of peace? Well, my situation is one of war, and that's why I keep my quills ready as long as a Wolf is around.'
option_a: No one can be safe in peace unless they are always ready to face an enemy in case of war.
option_b: Even the strongest can be brought low by unchecked desires.
option_d: Relying too much on cautious subordinates can lead to manipulative unintended consequences.
option_e: Strength without strategy can be easily outmaneuvered.
correct_moral: No one can be safe in peace unless they are always ready to face an enemy in case of war.

fable: A Simple Mouse happened to be nearby when a Kite got caught in a Net. The Kite begged the Mouse to help her get free. The Mouse gnawed a Hole in the Net and set the Kite free; and the Kite ate the Mouse for her trouble.
option_a: Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
option_b: Unequal matches bring misery.
option_d: Be cautious with naive promises made under trapped duress.
option_e: Even the smallest can offer the greatest help in times of need.
correct_moral: Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.

fable: In old times, when Jupiter was in the mood to grant requests, a Cockle asked that his house and body be all one piece. Jupiter replied that it would be a burden rather than a favor. 'Yes', said the Cockle, 'but it is a burden I would rather bear than live exposed to bad neighbors.'
option_a: Unwanted visits are a nuisance to a peaceful person's life.
option_b: Be content with your lot.
option_d: The wise value of money is not in its cautious possession but in its use.
option_e: Desires for simplicity can lead to unforeseen limitations.
correct_moral: Unwanted visits are a nuisance to a peaceful person's life.

fable: A Snake was convinced during a Cold Winter to let a Hedgehog into his Den. But once inside, the Hedgehog's spines were very uncomfortable for the Snake. So the Snake told him he must find another place, as the Den was too small for both of them. The Hedgehog replied, 'If you can't stay, you should leave. As for me, I'm quite happy here, and if you're not, you're free to go.'
option_a: Possession is nine-tenths of the law.
option_b: No one can be safe in peace unless they are always ready to face an enemy in case of war.
option_d: Where force is lacking, possessive cleverness must replace it, especially in uncomfortable situations.
option_e: Kindness can invite unexpected challenges.
correct_moral: Possession is nine-tenths of the law.

fable: A Fox and a Hare were once in a heated contest about which of them could manage best in the world. 'When I am chased,' said the Hare, 'I can show the dogs a clean pair of heels and run away from them easily.' 'And yet,' said the Fox, 'I have outsmarted more of them with my tricks and cunning than you ever did with your speed.'
option_a: Wisdom is far superior to strength.
option_b: A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
option_d: No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust a cunning, tricky person.
option_e: True capability is revealed through action, not argument.
correct_moral: Wisdom is far superior to strength.

fable: There was an old man, who, even in his frailty, still had thoughts of women. His spiritual advisor noticed this and gave him earnest advice about the desires of the flesh. The old man thanked him sincerely for his kind and Christian counsel, saying, 'With Heaven's help, I'll follow it. To be honest, I'm told it's not good for me, and truly, my body is no longer fit for such activities.'
option_a: Many people give up their vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
option_b: Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
option_d: Yield to all with frail earnestness and you will soon have nothing to yield.
option_e: Desires may persist, but wisdom lies in knowing their place.
correct_moral: Many people give up their vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.

fable: A certain impertinent, thoughtless fellow decided to visit a philosopher. He found him alone in his study and wondered how he could bear to live such a solitary life. The learned man told him, 'Sir, you are very mistaken; I was in very good company until you came in.'
option_a: Better to be alone than in bad company.
option_b: Act as you profess to believe.
option_d: Bear that those who are impertinent and thoughtless in merit should be like you in outside appearances.
option_e: Approaching wisdom with arrogance may leave one empty-handed.
correct_moral: Better to be alone than in bad company.

fable: There is a story of a Wolf that wrapped himself in a sheep's skin and attacked lambs for a while under that disguise. But the shepherd eventually caught him and hung him up, sheep's skin and all, on a high gallows as a warning and example. The neighbors were amazed and asked why he hung up his sheep. 'Oh,' he said, 'that's just the skin of a sheep that was used to cover the heart, malice, and body of a wolf that hid under it.'
option_a: People should not be judged by their appearances, but by their actions.
option_b: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
option_d: Putting up with one cunning insult invites another malicious one.
option_e: Those who hide their true nature may prey on the unsuspecting.
correct_moral: People should not be judged by their appearances, but by their actions.

fable: There was a Widow who had a desire for a Second Husband, and she asked a gossiping Friend of hers for help on how to handle it. 'The truth is,' she said, 'I really want another partner, but people would laugh and point at me, and it would make me miserable.' 'You're a fine Widow,' said the Friend, 'to worry about what people say. Listen to me now. You have a Donkey in your fields; go and have that Donkey painted Green, and then let him be shown around the Country. Do this without any more talk, because talk just wastes time.' So it was done, and for the first four or five days, the Green Donkey had the whole Country following him, men, women, and children, all staring and shouting. In four or five more days, the excitement was over, and the Donkey could travel all day without anyone noticing him. 'Now,' said the helpful Friend, 'a newly married Widow is like a Green Donkey: everyone talks about it for the first few days, and then the story fades away.'
option_a: There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of time.
option_b: It's good to be able to laugh at yourself.
option_d: Be your desirous self and don't pretend to be someone you're unnoticed not.
option_e: The fear of judgment can hinder the pursuit of happiness.
correct_moral: There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of time.

fable: A Shepherd had one favorite dog that he trusted more than all the others. He fed him by hand and cared for him more than any of the other dogs. This kindness continued for a long time until, when some sheep went missing, he suspected this dog of being unfaithful. After this suspicion, he watched him closely and eventually discovered that this trusted servant was the thief. Once he found out, he had the dog caught and told him to prepare for punishment. 'Oh, Master,' said the dog, 'I am part of your family, and it would be harsh to punish a household member. Turn your anger on the wolves instead, who regularly attack your sheep.' 'No, no,' said the Shepherd, 'I would rather spare forty wolves who make it their business to kill sheep than one sheep-stealing dog trusted with their care. There is some honesty and boldness in the wolves, but the dog's betrayal is the worst kind of treachery.'
option_a: An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.
option_b: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
option_c: Trust must be earned, not pleaded.
option_d: Nobody believes people who are inherently unfaithful, even if they pretend to be honest and good-natured.
option_e: Favoritism can breed dependency and neglect the strength of the whole.
correct_moral: An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.

fable: There was once a Ram who defeated all his fellow rams and became so proud of his victories that he decided to challenge a Bull to a fight. They met, and at the first clash, the Ram was knocked out and lay as if dead. When he came to, he said, 'This is the result of my arrogance and foolishness in challenging an enemy that nature made stronger than me.'
option_a: We should not pick fights with people stronger than we are.
option_b: He that has many friends, has no friends.
option_c: Arrogance often masks the fear of being outmatched.
option_d: A foolish, wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
option_e: In triumph, true strength is measured by the respect earned, not merely by defeating others.
correct_moral: We should not pick fights with people stronger than we are.

fable: A certain father, whose son had succumbed to vicious tendencies, was urging the boy at great length that he should quit the way of vices and keep his eye instead on the virtues, which would engender praise and honor for him. The son replied: 'You are wasting your time, Father, in urging me to do these things, for I have heard many a preacher, so to speak, and they urged me to the path of virtue with far more talent than you, but I have still never taken any of their advice!'
option_a: Men who are wickedly inclined will not stop their vicious behavior, no matter who urges them to do so.
option_b: Not all things are suitable for all people.
option_d: People often disguise their persuasive, selfish desires as stubborn, practical needs to justify their actions.
option_e: Virtue's guidance offers a light to overcome the shadow of vice.
correct_moral: Men who are wickedly inclined will not stop their vicious behavior, no matter who urges them to do so.

fable: There was an Eagle that took a nest of Rabbits and carried them away to her young. The Mother Rabbit followed her with tears in her eyes, pleading in the name of all the powers that protect the innocent and oppressed, to have mercy on her poor children. But the Eagle, in a fit of pride and anger, tore them to pieces. The Rabbit then gathered all the rabbits together, told her story, and sought advice on revenge. 'Divine justice,' she said, 'will not let such cruel acts go unpunished.' They discussed the matter and all agreed that the only way to repay the Eagle was to undermine the tree where she nested. So they all worked at the roots of the tree, leaving it with so little support that the first strong wind brought it crashing down, nest, Eagles, and all. Some of them were killed by the fall; others were eaten by birds and beasts of prey, and the Rabbit finally had the satisfaction of destroying the Eagle's children in revenge for her own.
option_a: It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
option_b: No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
option_d: Beware of prideful enterprizes where the vengeful risks are not equal.
option_e: Desperation can drive even the gentle to confront the mighty.
correct_moral: It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.

fable: There was a Master-Pike, who for his size, beauty, and strength, was seen as the Prince of the River. But being the ruler of the freshwater wasn't enough for him; he wanted to rule the sea too. With this ambitious plan, he ventured into the ocean and claimed it as his own. However, a mighty Dolphin took offense at this intrusion and chased the Pike back to the edge of his own stream, barely allowing him to escape. From then on, the Pike wisely stayed within his own territory.
option_a: Be content with your lot.
option_b: Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
option_d: Ambitious counsel without mighty help is useless.
option_e: True leadership is not just about appearance, but also about actions.
correct_moral: Be content with your lot.

fable: A Sheep that was about to be sheared was upset with the Shepherd for not being content with the Milk she provided, but also taking her Wool. The Shepherd, without further words, angrily took one of the Lambs and killed it. 'Well,' said the Sheep, 'I hope you've done your worst now.' 'No,' said the Shepherd, 'when that's done, I can cut your throat too if I want, and throw you to the Dogs or Wolves as I please.' The Sheep said nothing more, fearing something worse might happen.
option_a: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
option_b: An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.
option_c: Fear can turn innocence into danger.
option_d: Take what you can get when you can get it in a ruthless, threatening world.
option_e: Gratitude is often overshadowed by the desire for more.
correct_moral: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.

fable: The coachman, hearing one of the wheels of his coach creak, was surprised; but more especially when he perceived that it was the worst wheel of the whole set, and which he thought had but little pretense to take such a liberty.
option_a: Complaining is the privilege of the weak.
option_b: It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
option_d: Be observant and wise to know your enemies.
option_e: Noise often masks vulnerability.
correct_moral: Complaining is the privilege of the weak.

fable: There was a generous Rich Man who always had a grand and open table, so he never lacked guests. This man noticed that all sorts of people came to him, and he became curious to see who were true friends and who were just freeloaders. So one day, at a full table, he mentioned a quarrel he had and said he was about to seek satisfaction. He needed a certain number of people to join him, and he was sure they would stand by him with swords in hand. Everyone made excuses except for two, whom he counted as his friends, while the rest were just hangers-on.
option_a: True friends are hard to come by.
option_b: A man cannot be too careful of what he does, where the life of any creature is in question.
option_d: Excuse-making people adjust their loyal beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
option_e: Generosity attracts company, but sincerity keeps it.
correct_moral: True friends are hard to come by.

fable: As a Dog was chasing closely behind a Fox, a Hare suddenly appeared. 'Hold on a moment,' said the Fox, 'and catch that Hare while you can. You've never tasted such a treat in your life. But I'm all spoiled and rotten, and a bite of my flesh would poison you.' The Dog immediately left the Fox and chased after the Hare, but she was too quick for him. When he realized he couldn't catch her, he wisely let her go. The Hare had overheard what happened, and when she met the Fox a few days later, she told him how badly he had treated her. 'Well,' said the Fox, 'if you are upset that I spoke well of you, what would you have done if I had spoken badly?'
option_a: A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
option_b: Wisdom is far superior to strength.
option_d: A single persistent skill is worth more than a bag of cunning tricks.
option_e: Opportunism can divert focus from the original goal.
correct_moral: A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.

fable: The rabbit and the fox made their petitions to Jupiter: the fox asked that swiftness of foot be added to her slyness, and the rabbit asked that slyness be added to his swiftness. Jupiter responded to them as follows: 'From the beginning of the world, from my breast I have poured forth gifts to each and every animal very generously; if I were to give one animal all the fits, that would be an injury to the others.'
option_a: Be content with your lot.
option_b: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
option_d: Not all advice is sly or wise.
option_e: Desiring more than one's nature can lead to imbalance.
correct_moral: Be content with your lot.

fable: Quite a few horses had been brought to the race track, all adorned with elaborate accoutrements, all except for one, so the other horses made fun of him for being so shabby and unsuited to this type of competition, and they concluded that he would not ever be a winner. But when the time for the running of the race arrived and the trumpet blew the signal to start, all the horses leaped from their starting cages, and only then did it become clear how much the horse who had just been made fun of actually outdistanced the rest of the horses with his speed. When all the others had been left far behind, that horse won the palm of victory.
option_a: Appearances can be deceiving.
option_b: Be cautious of pride, as nobody knows what the future may bring.
option_c: Mocking others can hinder true victory.
option_d: Accept the fast, victorious changes in life.
option_e: Perseverance can outpace initial setbacks.
correct_moral: Appearances can be deceiving.

fable: A Countryman who was caught up in a lawsuit had a close friend and relative who was a lawyer. He went to him again and again for advice, but the lawyer was always too busy and told him to come back another time. The poor man took a nice, fat kid goat with him on his next visit, and when the lawyer's clerk heard the goat at the door, he let the man in and took him to his master. There, the man explained his case, got the lawyer's opinion, thanked the lawyer for seeing him, and thanked the goat for getting him in, and then went on his way.
option_a: Money opens all doors.
option_b: Experience often provides clearer insight than empty predictions.
option_d: The persistent, loud-mouthed boaster does not impress nor frighten those who are perceptive and know him.
option_e: Familiarity does not guarantee fairness.
correct_moral: Money opens all doors.

fable: A certain young man had married a woman who was also quite young, very beautiful and lusty. Wanting to satisfy her boundless appetite, his loins had gotten so worn out that after just a few days he had gotten thin and looked more dead than alive: he could not walk, he could not stand up, he could do any kind of work, and so like some kind of old man he took his pleasure in the sun. So when he was enjoying some sunny place, warming himself by the sun's heat, it happened that some hunters, who had been chasing a wolf, came that way. When the young man asked them why they hadn't caught the wolf, they replied, 'We were not able to pursue him because of his incredible swiftness.' 'Well,' he said, 'if my wife were in charge of him, she'd put an end to his running.'
option_a: Even the strongest can be brought low by unchecked desires.
option_b: Each man makes his reputation in the field which is his specialty.
option_d: A beautiful honest man's swift word is as good as his oath.
option_e: True harmony requires more than surface attraction.
correct_moral: Even the strongest can be brought low by unchecked desires.

fable: An Old Man caught a Boy stealing apples from his orchard. 'Hey,' he said, 'come down from that tree and stop taking my apples.' The Boy ignored him and kept picking. 'Well,' said the Old Man, 'they say herbs have magic just like words do,' and he threw a handful of grass at the Boy. This was so silly that the Young Thief thought the Old Man was joking. But finally, the Old Man said, 'If words and herbs won't work, I'll try stones, because they say stones have power too,' and with that, he got the job done.
option_a: Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
option_b: Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
option_d: Every wise tale is not to be defiant believed.
option_e: A gentle confrontation can lead to understanding and change.
correct_moral: Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.

fable: As a Nightingale was singing in a bush, down swoops a sneaky Sparrow-Hawk and snatches her from the branch. The poor Nightingale pleaded for her life, saying that her small body wasn't worth it and that there were bigger birds to catch. The Hawk replied, 'Do you think I'm so foolish as to give up a little bird I have for a bigger one I don't have?' Then she offered, 'I'll sing you a lovely song for my life.' 'No, no,' said the Hawk, 'I need food for my belly, not music for my ears.'
option_a: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
option_b: Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
option_c: Small actions can have sneaky impacts.
option_d: People who grasp at more than they need lose the small, sneaky little that they held in their hands.
option_e: Even in moments of beauty, one must remain vigilant.
correct_moral: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.

fable: A Lion, who found it very bothersome to live alone, let the Beasts of the Forest know that he had decided to choose one of them as a Friend and Companion. There was a great commotion about who would be the Favorite and the envy of all the others. The Lion chose a Hog, saying, 'He is true and faithful to his friend and will stand by him in all times and dangers.'
option_a: Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.
option_b: No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
option_d: Bothersome small liberties can be true large offenses.
option_e: Loneliness can drive even the mighty to seek companionship.
correct_moral: Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.

fable: A Gnat, nearly frozen and hungry, went to a Bee-Hive on a cold morning to ask for help. The Gnat offered to teach music to the Bee's family in exchange for food and shelter. The Bee politely declined, saying, 'I teach all my children my own trade so they can earn a living through hard work.'
option_a: Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
option_b: It's better to ignore an insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
option_d: Hardworking, fine work gets frozen, preserved, and treasured.
option_e: In times of need, humility can open doors to unexpected kindness.
correct_moral: Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.

fable: When a war broke out between the Birds and the Beasts, the Lion called all his subjects from ages sixteen to sixty to gather with weapons at a specific time and place, or face his great displeasure. Among those who showed up were many Asses and Hares. Some of the leaders wanted to dismiss them, thinking they were not fit for service. 'Do not be mistaken,' said the Lion, 'the Asses will do well as trumpeters, and the Hares will make excellent letter-carriers.'
option_a: No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
option_b: Be prepared to defend your position.
option_d: Commanding yet unfit, arrogant fools have no true influence.
option_e: Threats and orders breed fear, not loyalty.
correct_moral: No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.

fable: Once there was a fierce civil war among the Hawks. The gentle and innocent Pigeons, out of pure kindness, sent their representatives to try and make peace between them. While the Hawks were busy fighting each other, they paid no attention to anything else. But as soon as they made peace, they returned to their old habit of attacking the Pigeons. This made the Pigeons realize their mistake and understand the danger of helping a common enemy, which led to their own downfall.
option_a: The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.
option_b: Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
option_d: Beware the fierce sort of innocent person who uses tricks.
option_e: Internal strife weakens even the strongest forces.
correct_moral: The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.

fable: There is a story that Death visited an Old Man and told him to come along. The Man tried to excuse himself, saying that the journey to the Other World was too long to take on such short notice, and he asked for a little more time to make his Will before he died. Death replied, 'You have had enough warning, one would think, to have been ready by now.' 'In truth,' said the Old Man, 'this is the first time I have ever seen you in my whole life.' 'That's not true,' said Death, 'for you have seen daily examples of mortality before your eyes, in people of all kinds, ages, and ranks. Isn't the frequent sight of others' deaths a reminder enough to make you think of your own? Your dim and hollow eyes, the loss of your hearing, and the faltering of your other senses should remind you, without much ado, that Death has already taken hold of you. And do you think this is the time to keep putting it off? Your final hour, I tell you, has now come, and there's no thought of a reprieve in the case of Fate.'
option_a: We should live as if we always saw Death standing by.
option_b: Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
option_c: Old age can bring deadly consequences if unprepared.
option_d: Unprepared people often make extravagant, excuse-making promises which they are completely unable to carry out.
option_e: The signs of aging should serve as reminders of our mortality.
correct_moral: We should live as if we always saw Death standing by.

fable: There was a certain miserly man who was dying and about to part with his enormous heap of money, ill-gotten as it was. He ordered that the bag of coins be brought to him as he was dying and then asked the bag to whom it would bring pleasure. The bag answered him: 'I'm going to bring pleasure to your heirs, who will squander these coins, over which you sweated, on women and drinks, and I'll also bring pleasure to the demons who are going to turn your soul over to eternal torments.'
option_a: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
option_b: It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
option_d: Even beneficial things all appear to be enormous and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced, making them seem tormenting.
option_e: The fruits of toil may not always yield the intended legacy.
correct_moral: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.

fable: An elm tree sprang up on the bank of a river, and the elm tree mocked the willow tree who was her neighbor for being weak and feeble, as it bent with every surge of the water, no matter how light, while the elm tree praised her own stoutness and strength with extravagant words, because for many years the elm tree had remained unshaken by even the most persistent movement of the stream. On one occasion, however, the elm tree snapped from the tremendous violence of the waves and as she was being dragged along by the waters the willow tree laughed and said: Why are you abandoning me, neighbor? Where is your stoutness now?'
